ygData.subject: Re: Replace genotypic distance and speciation mechanisms in hyperNEAT by a novelty distance comparison on the outputs of the CPPN
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Paul, good question.  I don t know of anyone who has specifically tried your idea, but I can give you my thoughts: As you know, what you re proposing is

Subject: Re: Replace genotypic distance and speciation mechanisms in hyperNEAT by a novelty distance comparison on the outputs of the CPPN
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=pVSD3wB5_kS9PeGi5H4cZFOBoKWDm0RQAv-J3B8TV1MNQh1V5u4Y
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Hi Paul, good question.  I don't know of anyone who has specifically
tried =
your idea, but I can give you my thoughts: As you know, what
you're proposi=
ng is sort of between genetic diversity and "behavioral"
diversity. Whereas=
 behavior would usually be defined as the actions
taken by an agent during =
its lifetime, you are instead looking at the
neural network substrate that =
produces the behavior (which is indirectly
encoded by a CPPN) rather than l=
ooking at the behavior itself.

In any case, the idea raises some interesti=
ng questions.  My feeling is
that it will not work as well as genetic diver=
sity, although it does
provide some benefits, which means that in some doma=
ins the difference
between the two approaches may be difficult to discern. =
 However, I
believe that in particular when you are hoping for something ve=
ry
complex to evolve (i.e. something that requires a big CPPN to encode),
t=
raditional genetic diversity based on historical markings in the CPPN
would=
 be superior.

The reason for my hypothesis is that the genetic diversity m=
echanism in
NEAT is not only an attempt to provide diversity to avoid decep=
tion. 
More than that, it is meant to protect innovative structural changes=
. 
That is, when new structure is initially added to a CPPN through a
mutat=
ion, the resulting fitness is often not better and probably worse
than befo=
re the structure was added.  However, we do not want to throw
away such inn=
ovative structures too soon because they may pay off if we
let them optimiz=
e for more generations.  Hence such novel structures are
protected in new s=
pecies by NEAT.  (The problem of losing innovative
structures can indeed al=
so be interpreted as a kind of deception, but it
is not the traditional kin=
d of deception considered in optimization of
fixed-sized search spaces.)

I=
f you think about the weight pattern output by the CPPN (as you
propose), t=
hen you can imagine that random structural additions to the
CPPN may often =
lead to degenerate output weight patterns that are
similar to each other (s=
uch as weight patterns with all weights
saturated).  Such CPPNs would not l=
ook diverse from the perspective of
your proposed mechanism.  However, my v=
iew is that they should look
diverse because their CPPNs have different str=
ucture, and we want to
isolate unique structure to give it an opportunity t=
o optimize (which is
the general principle in NEAT).

The converse problema=
tic situation is when new structure is added to the
CPPN but the output wei=
ght pattern does not change much, which is also
possible.  I would argue th=
at such an augmented structure should be
protected so we can see whether it=
 optimizes to improve performance in
the future, but your mechanism would v=
iew it as nothing new (because it
produced nothing new) and hence likely lo=
se it in future generations,
unless it immediately boosts fitness.

One imp=
ortant consequence of genetic speciation in NEAT is
complexification.  That=
 is, protecting novel structures helps CPPNs (or
ANNs in original NEAT) inc=
rease in complexity because it protects
structural innovations that would o=
therwise be penalized for reducing
fitness.  So one hypothesis (that we hav=
e seen supported in preliminary
tests) is that a system relying entirely on=
 behavioral diversity will
not effectively add complexity to CPPNs, even wh=
en it would be helpful. 
Thus in domains that do not require much complexit=
y, you may not notice
a problem, but in domains that do, the problem will e=
merge.

In general, there has been some discussion lately (aside from your =
idea)
that the recent successes of behavioral diversity techniques like
nov=
elty search might imply that we can drop NEAT's genetic diversity
mechanism=
. However, I would caution against jumping to this conclusion
too soon.   W=
hile I am sure that in some domains you can get equivalent
or even better p=
erformance, in the long run I believe that genetic
diversity plays a differ=
ent and complementary role to behavioral
diversity, in part to protect stru=
ctural innovation.

My interpretation of the benefits of behavioral diversi=
ty is different
than the emerging popular interpretation:  I believe that p=
ositive
results with behavioral diversity are confirmations of the deleteri=
ous
effect of objectives rather than evidence that we should combine
tradit=
ional fitness-based objectives with behavioral diversity.  While
such combi=
nations may work with traditional modest objectives (i.e. in
benchmark prob=
lems of the variety popular today), behavioral diversity
will prove only a =
placebo when paired with much more ambitious
objectives.  That is, the more=
 ambitious we become, the less useful
traditional fitness-based objectives =
will be, even as behavioral
diversity/novelty alone remains important in it=
s own right (i.e. when
not paired with a traditional objective).

Of course=
, much of this post is speculative, but it is my best guess
based on my exp=
erience and understanding of the algorithms and
representations involved.

=
ken
--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tonelli <nemo136@...> wrote:
>
> Hell=
o,
>
> I am currently experimenting with hyperNEAT and was just wondering i=
f
> anybody tried to replace the NEAT mechanisms found in hyperNEAT
(specia=
tion,
> distance based on innovation numbers and weights in the cppn) by a
=
distance
> between the behaviors of the CPPN.  This may not be clear, so I =
will
> developp:
>
> The NEAT part in hyperNEAT improves the evolution of C=
PPNs, and, if
you
> remove both the speciation protection mechanism and the=
 distance
between
> genotypes based on the innovation numbers, the "HyperNe=
uralNetwork"
has bad
> fitnesses on the different benchmarks (the fitness l=
andscape of the
cppn
> seems to be quite deceptive).
>
> However, consideri=
ng the recent results on diversity and novelty
objectives,
> has anybody tr=
ied to replace them (innovation numbers and speciation
> mechanisms) with a=
n explicit objective which would take into account
the
> novelty of behavio=
r of the CPPN ?
>
> This is straightforward to implement for a given substr=
ate: for each
query
> of the cppn of an individual (each time you compute a=
 weight between
two
> substrate nodes), append the obtained weight to a vec=
tor. It is then
> possible to define a novelty objective based on a convent=
ional
distance
> metric between these "CPPN Behavior" vectors.
>
> An addit=
ionnal benefit I see from this approach, and if I understood
neat
> innovat=
ion numbers correctly, is that the mathematical functions used
for
> each n=
ode in the cppn are not taken into account by the neat metric
(if two
> nod=
es with a same innovation number have mutated to present different
> mathem=
atical functions, this does not increase the NEAT distance
between
> them).=

>
> I have already have preliminary results showing that this metric is an=

> improvement over my partial implementation of hyperNEAT, however, I
only=

> used a distance based on the innovation numbers and not the species
> pr=
otection mechanism.
>
> Paul
>
